p: Downstream adaptor protein molecules for TLRs, MyD88 (for TLR4, TLR7, TLR8) and TRIF (for TLR3, TLR4), are required for protection against coronavirus infections, indicating the essential role of innate sensing in host immunity. Mice deficient in MyD88 challenged with mouse-adapted SARS-CoV are unable to control viral replication and succumb to infection ( Sheahan et al., 2008). Mice deficient in TRIF are also highly susceptible to SARS-CoV, with morbidity comparable to the MyD88-deficient mice ( Totura et al., 2015). In MERS-CoV infection, lack of MyD88 signaling results in delayed viral clearance and increased lung pathology ( Zhao et al., 2014). By contrast, this study did not find a requirement for MAVS signaling, which is downstream of RLR sensing. Consistently, another study showed that Tlr7 −/− mice, but not Mavs −/− mice, have reduced IFN expression compared with wild-type mice ( Channappanavar et al., 2019). This suggests that TLR7-MyD88 is the primary pathway of innate immune sensing in MERS-CoV infection.
